title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text: Graphics API: Processing

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text: Grammar of Graphics

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Altair


import altair as alt
from vega_datasets import data
source = data.iowa_electricity()
alt.Chart(source).mark_area(opacity=0.3).encode(
  x="year:T",
  y=alt.Y("net_generation:Q").stack(None),
  color="source:N"
)

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Data
Graphics start with data

# Load required libraries and data
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(openxlsx)
library(flextable)

# Load data from an Excel spreadsheet
data <- read.xlsx("./healthcare cost data.xlsx")

# View the data
flextable(head(data))

Patient.CountAgeDiseaseInsurer.CostPatient.%.of.CostPatient.CostPer.Patient.CostTotal.Cost1,4051Acid Reflux3,901,661.80.1685064790,691.763,339.7534,692,353.53042Acid Reflux858,277.70.1709969177,035.323,405.6351,035,313.01423Acid Reflux420,850.90.167017284,382.723,557.983505,233.71074Acid Reflux307,946.40.167047961,758.393,455.185369,704.8985Acid Reflux392,417.40.147309967,793.614,696.030460,211.0936Acid Reflux273,932.50.165479954,319.023,529.586328,251.5

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text: Aesthetics

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Mapping
How to map data onto aesthetic attributes of geometric objects

ggplot(data, aes(x = Patient.Count, y = Total.Cost))

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Layers

A graph is made of one or more layers
Each layer has three parts:

Geometry determines how data are displayed (points, lines, etc.)
Statistical transformations affect what is displayed

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Geometries
Describe geometries

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Geometries: Point

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_point()

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Geometries: Point, colored by Disease

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Disease))

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Geometries: Line, colored by Disease

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = Disease))

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Geometries: Line + Point

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = Disease)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Disease))

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Scales
Scales map data values to aesthetic values. Here we change the default color scale used for Disease

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = Disease)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Disease)) +
  scale_color_viridis_d()

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Facets

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = Disease)) +
  facet_wrap(~ Disease)

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Facets (without color coding)

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_line() +
  facet_wrap(~ Disease)

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Statistics

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_point(aes(color=Disease)) +
  geom_line(aes(color=Disease)) +
  stat_summary(geom="line", fun="mean")

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Coordinates

ggplot(data, aes(x = Age, y = Total.Cost)) +
  geom_point(aes(color=Disease)) +
  geom_line(aes(color=Disease)) +
  stat_summary(geom="line", fun="mean")

title: Taxonomy of Visualization Tools
text:
Code
When you click the Render button a presentation will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. \(x_1 = 10\) You can embed code like this:
